subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: WEB Project moving foreward
msgSnippet: From: Timothy tim_rice09@yahoo.com Received: Sunday, April 22, 2012, 12:51 AM    (with the exception of the letter Ayin, which is commonly pronounced as a
messageBody:
From: Timothy tim_rice09@...
Received: Sunday, April 22, 2012, 12:51 AM

 
 (with the exception of the letter Ayin, which is commonly pronounced as a glottal stop anyway).
 
-0-
 
Speaking as someone whose late father davened (prayed) in Bevis Marks Synagogue, the oldest synagogue in England, and whose older relatives
at family [Passover] seders pronounced the ayin in a distinctive way,
I wish to inform you that the traditional pronounciation of ayin in the
Spanish and Portuguese Jewish Community of London (England) was somewhat
different.
 
You can read about it here.
 
http://sites.google.com/site/londonsephardiminhag/pronunciation
 
The word minhag is a Hebrew word; in the context of Judaism and more 
specifically of Jewish services, it means custom, in the sense of whatever
customs obtain with regards to Jewish religious services in the synagogue.
 
David Pinto
Montreal, Canada
david_e_pinto@...
